comments:
I'm able to (natively) build and use Eclipse 3.2 milestone 3 and 4 but not 5.

Eclipse 3.2M5, i have to patch to build:

--- plugins/org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility.registry/build.xml	2006-02-20 19:59:07.000000000 +0100
+++ plugins/org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility.registry/build.xml.new	2006-02-20 19:59:36.000000000 +0100
@@ -58,6 +58,7 @@
 		<path id="runtime_registry_compatibility.jar.classpath">
 			<pathelement path="../org.eclipse.equinox.registry/runtime_registry_compatibility.jar"/>
 			<pathelement path="../org.eclipse.equinox.registry/@dot"/>
+			<pathelement path="../org.eclipse.core.runtime/@dot"/>
 			<pathelement path="${build.result.folder}/../org.eclipse.osgi/@dot"/>
 			<pathelement path="${build.result.folder}/../org.eclipse.core.jobs/bin/"/>
 			<pathelement path="${build.result.folder}/../org.eclipse.core.jobs/@dot"/>
			

to circumvent this:

    [javac] 1. ERROR in /usr/pkgsrc/Eclipse3.2M5/eclipse320/work/plugins/org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility.registry/src/org/eclipse/core/internal/registry/ExtensionHandle.java

    [javac]  (at line 13)

    [javac] 	import org.eclipse.core.runtime.IPluginDescriptor;

    [javac] 	       ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

    [javac] The import org.eclipse.core.runtime.IPluginDescriptor cannot be resolved


now milestone 5 does build.

furthermore i have to skip the package part:

--- build.xml	2006-02-21 04:54:16.000000000 +0100
+++ build.xml.new	2006-02-21 04:53:24.000000000 +0100
@@ -141,11 +141,6 @@
 			and help indeces.-->
 			<property name="doc.zip.present" value="true" />
 		</ant>
-		<ant antfile="package.org.eclipse.sdk.${installOs}.${installWs}.${installArch}.xml">
-			<!--set property to delay building of doc.zips to later.  Doc built in this step would be missing extension point doc
-			and help indeces.-->
-			<property name="doc.zip.present" value="true" />
-		</ant>
 		<antcall target="build.doc.plugins" />
 		<echo message="Done." />
 	</target>

given this message:

/usr/pkgsrc/Eclipse3.2M5/eclipse320/work/package.org.eclipse.sdk.linux.motif.x86.xml:71: Warning: Could not find file /usr/pkgsrc/Eclipse3.2M5/eclipse320/work/result/org.eclipse.sdk-I20060217-1115-linux.motif.x86.zip to copy.


there is a result/linux-motif-x86-sdk.tar.gz

if i deploy and try to use at:

java -version
java version "1.4.2-p8"
Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.4.2-p8-root_09_jan_2006_12_23)
Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.4.2-p8-root_09_jan_2006_12_23, mixed mode)

uname -a
NetBSD 10.0.2.9 3.0 NetBSD 3.0 (GENERIC.ACPI) #0: Thu Jan 26 03:38:32 CET 2006 root@10.0.2.9:/usr/src/sys/arch/i386/compile/GENERIC.ACPI i386

I have the same problem with eclipse 3.2RC1.
I'm trying to build with gentoo linux, amd64, sun java 5.0.

As the original submitter discovered it really just seems to be a missing classpath entry and should equally affect all platforms.
You need to have both 1.4 and 1.5 java libraries installed at build time now, see bug 134852.
Please reopen if you encounter problems building eclipse from source with both 1.4 and 1.5 java libraries installed.

I would not like to think that the jdk version has anything to do with the problem unless the ant scripts have specific tests for jdk versions. Importing a class that is not in the classpath should fail equally on all jdk versions.


Side note: I do wonder why a jdk 1.4 dependency has been added to the build system. It sounds like a big regression to me because the eclipse 3.1M5 - 3.1.2 ebuilds all build nicely with only jdk 5.0.

I am able to build the 3.2rc1a with only jdk 5.0 but I still need the one extra line in the classpath as defined in this bug. I do not see how adding a new entry to the classpath would fail to compile on jdk 1.4 so I think it would be good to patch the builds regardless of if the official ruling is to use both jdk 1.4 and jdk 5.0.

Mikko, in order to compile runtime.compatibility and break a circular dependency we play a trick whereby the plugin includes a class file of the IPluginDescriptor (see the project in cvs).

The goal behind using multiple class libraries at compile time is to respect the constraint expressed by each bundle in the Bundle-ExecutionEnvironement property. By not playing by the rule of compiling against the appropriate JRE, you expose your self to random warnings, but also maybe missing methods, etc. when people will specify EE from embedded platforms.

no problem building/using native libraries and Eclipse up to/including 3.2M4.

as per 3.2M5 up to RC4 i build using Java 4 and 5 conform
http://download.eclipse.org/eclipse/downloads/drops/S-3.2M5-200602171115/srcIncludedBuildInstructions.html
build -os linux -ws gtk -arch x86 -compilelibs -java5home /usr/pkg/java/jdk-1.5.0

but i have to patch plugins/org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility.registry/build.xml:
+<pathelement path="${build.result.folder}/../org.eclipse.core.runtime/bin/"/>
+<pathelement path="${build.result.folder}/../org.eclipse.core.runtime/@dot"/>

if not i get:
The import org.eclipse.core.runtime.IPluginDescriptor cannot be resolved

the result does not run..so patch isn't valid.

if i then replace the just build:
plugins/org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility.registry_3.2.0.v20060426/runtime_registry_compatibility.jar
with runtime_registry_compatibility.jar from the linux x86 binary download
the newly build Eclipse does run.

as Pascal is telling us there's a trick involved to build.
but i don't understand him telling us how to do the trick.

plz. elude me.. what extra to do besides:
build -os linux -ws gtk -arch x86 -compilelibs -java5home /usr/pkg/java/jdk-1.5.0

so

pre-build:
	rm ${WRKDIR}/plugins/org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility.registry/classes/org/eclipse/core/runtime/IPluginDescriptor.class
	ln -sf ${WRKDIR}/plugins/org.eclipse.core.runtime/@dot/org/eclipse/core/runtime/IPluginDescriptor.class ${WRKDIR}/plugins/org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility.registry/classes/org/eclipse/core/runtime/IPluginDescriptor.class

..got the trick..and now have a working Eclipse 3.2RC4 ;)
(no need for my patch)
